thread.title: Bulls' Jimmy Butler on trade talks: 'Nothing I can do about it'
thread.title_full: Bulls' Jimmy Butler on trade talks: 'Nothing I can do about it'

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: Bulls' Jimmy Butler on trade talks: 'Nothing I can do about it'
text:
Bulls' Jimmy Butler on trade talks: 'Nothing I can do about it' In the midst of the best season of his career, the Bulls' star stayed mum on trade rumors. Post to Facebook Bulls' Jimmy Butler on trade talks: 'Nothing I can do about it' In the midst of the best season of his career, the Bulls' star stayed mum on trade rumors.  //usat.ly/2m5JpdL   Bulls' Jimmy Butler on trade talks: 'Nothing I can do about it' Kevin Spain , USA TODAY Sports 8:22 p.m. ET Feb. 17, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' AJ Neuharth-Keusch breaks down the top story lines to watch at the 2017 NBA All-Star Game. USA TODAY Sports Jimmy Butler during the All Star media availability at the Ritz Carlton. (Photo: Derick E. Hingle, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
NEW ORLEANS – Jimmy Butler speaks his mind and sometimes, he admits, it causes him trouble. But he’s open and honest when asked questions, which is refreshing in the world of playerspeak that often devolves into tired clichés and little substance. 
But Butler isn’t too open about his view on the chatter that he could be traded from Chicago. Well, that’s not entirely true. He shared an opinion when asked Friday during media day for the NBA All Star Game. It just seemed a little, subdued. 
“I don’t know if I deserve to be traded. That’s not in my job description,” he said. “I’m just here to play basketball to the best of my ability. If I’m here, I’m here.” 
The fact that Butler’s name is mentioned in trade talks seems strange. He’s the best player on this year’s Bulls team and is having his best season as a pro. 
MORE NBA: NBAPA's Chris Paul, Michele Roberts lament Charles Oakley-Knicks incident 
He’s putting up 24.5 points, five assists and 6.3 rebounds for a team that, with a 28-29 record, is viewed as underachieving. He’s in the third year of a five-year $95 million contract and it would seem like the team should be building around him instead of thinking about moving him. 
“Nothing I can do about it,” he said when asked about if there’s talk about trade rumors. “Control what you can control. Why talk about it? Why worry about it? If you’re here, you’re here. If you’re not, you’re not.” 
Fair enough. But what if he did get moved? Where could he go? While there should be several teams lined up for Butler’s services, one that might be at the top of the list is the Boston Celtics, who are second in the East, but who could be facing some serious competition in their quest to unseat the Cleveland Cavaliers at the top. Nance won the contest, which was the first in the NBA. Porter Binks, USAT 1986: Despite his diminutive stature, Spud Webb would go on to win the 1986 Slam Dunk Contest in dazzling fashion. USA TODAY Sports 1988: Michael Jordan attempts his "Rock the Cradle" dunk during the 1988 competition in Chicago. He would take home the trophy that year. John Swart, AP 1991: Dee Brown goes up for a no-look slam dunk during the Slam Dunk Contest in Charlotte. Brown would win the contest that year. Nathaniel S. Butler, NBAE/Getty Images 1994: Isaiah "JR" Rider of the skies for a slam dunk during the 1994 Slam Dunk Contest. He is most remembered for his "East Bay Funk" dunk in the contest, which he would win. Nathaniel S. Butler, NBAE/Getty Images 1996: Kobe Bryant attempts a one-handed dunk during the 1996 Slam Dunk Contest. He would go on to win it that year. Andrew D. Bernstein, NBAE/Getty Images 2000: Toronto's Vince Carter passes the ball between his legs as he hangs in the air during the NBA Slam Dunk Contest. Carter won the competition. ROBERT HANASHIRO, USAT 2000: Steve Francis goes up for a reverse dunk. Despite his display of athleticism, Vince Carter would come away the winner of the competition. ROBERT HANASHIRO, USAT 2000: Tracy McGrady throws down a dunk during the 2000 Slam Dunk Contest. Despite that, he would fall to his cousin, Vince Carter, in the competition. Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports 2000: Vince Carter sticks his arm in the rim after dunking. This dunk would be referred to as the "Honey Dip." Carter won the competition. Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports 2002: Jason Richardson goes for a reverse dunk during the Slam Dunk Contest in Philadelphia. Richardson won the contest. Nathaniel S. Butler, NBAE/Getty Images 2004: Fred Jones of the Indiana Pacers won the Slam Dunk Contest beating two time champion Jason Richardson of the Golden State Warriors in a miss-filled dunk contest in Los Angeles. Dan MacMedan, USA TODAY Sports 2005: Josh Smith dons an old-time Atlanta Hawks jersey in honor of Dominique Wilkins during the NBA Rising Stars Slam Dunk contest in Denver. He would go on to win the contest. Michael Madrid, USA TODAY Sports 2005: Amare Stoudemire goes between the legs during the Slam Dunk Contest held in Denver. Josh Smith would come out the victor that year. Michael Madrid, USA TODAY Sports 2005: Josh Smith jumps over Kenyon Martin during the Slam Dunk Contest. Michael Madrid, USA TODAY Sports 2007: Gerald Green jumps over Nate Robinson of the New York Knicks, during the slam dunk contest during NBA All-Star weekend in Las Vegas. He would finish the contest as the winner. Kevork Djansezian, AP 2007: Gerald Green leaps over a table on his dunk in the finals of the NBA Slam Dunk Contest. Green won the competition, beating out eventual three-time winner, Nate Robinson. Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports 2008: Dwight Howard attempts a dunk from the free throw line with Superman outfit on. Howard's showmanship would lead to a victory in the contest. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Sports 2009: Dwight Howard emerges from a phone booth with a Superman cape on. Despite his theatrics, he would lose to Nate Robinson. Andrew D. Bernstein, NBAE/Getty Images 2009: Nate Robinson leaps over Dwight Howard en route to his second Slam Dunk Contest victory. Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports 2011: Blake Griffin emulates Vince Carter's "Honey Dip" dunk 11 years prior by sticking his arm into the basket. Griffin would win the contest that year. Mark J. Terrill, AP 2011: Oklahoma City's Serge Ibaka grabs a toy off the rim with his teeth during the Sprite Slam Dunk contest, part of the 2011 NBA All Star weekend in Los Angeles. However, Blake Griffin would win the competition. Robert Hanashiro, USAT 2011: Blake Griffin from dunks over a car with Baron Davis inside before winning the All-Star Slam Dunk Contest. Mark Ralston, AFP/Getty Images 2013: Terrence Ross attempts a behind-the-back dunk during the 2013 contest. Ross would win the contest. Brett Davis, USA TODAY Sports 2015: Zach LaVine brings the ball behind his back, toward his knees, for a dunk during the 2015 Slam Dunk Contest in Brooklyn. LaVine would take home the title that year. Bob Donnan, USA TODAY Sports 2016: Zach LaVine took home the title for the second year in a row, winning the contest in Toronto.
